title: Swimming at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre backstroke
text:
{{Infobox Olympic event |event = Women's 100 metre backstroke |games = 2004 Summer |image = |caption = |venue = [[Athens Olympic Aquatic Centre]] |date = August 15, 2004 (heats &
semifinals)
August 16, 2004 (final) |competitors = 41 |nations = 34 |win_value = 1:00.17 {{OlyR|swimming}} |gold = [[Natalie Coughlin]] |goldNOC = USA |silver = [[Kirsty Coventry]] |silverNOC = ZIM |bronze = [[Laure Manaudou]] |bronzeNOC = FRA |prev = [[Swimming at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre backstroke|2000]] |next = [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre backstroke|2008]]}} {{SwimmingAt2004SummerOlympics}} The '''women's 100 metre [[backstroke swimming|backstroke]]''' event at the [[2004 Olympic Games]] was contested at the [[Athens Olympic Aquatic Centre|Olympic Aquatic Centre]] of the [[Athens Olympic Sports Complex]] in [[Athens]], [[Greece]] on August 15 and 16.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympics_2004/swimming/schedule/3534120.stm |title=Swimming schedule |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=5 August 2004|accessdate=17 June 2007}} U.S. swimmer [[Natalie Coughlin]] won the gold medal in this event, outside the record time of 1:00.37. The silver medal was awarded to Zimbabwe's [[Kirsty Coventry]], who finished behind Coughlin by 0.13 of a second, breaking an African record of 1:00.50. France's [[Laure Manaudou]], who won the gold in the [[Swimming at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metre freestyle|400 m freestyle]] on the previous day, took home the bronze medal, with a time of 1:00.88.{{cite news|title=Coughlin takes gold in 100-meter backstroke|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/athens/swimming/2004-08-16-womens-roundup_x.htm|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=16 August 2004|accessdate=21 March 2013}} In the semifinals, Coughlin lowered an Olympic record time of 1:00.21, set by Romania's [[Diana Mocanu]] in Sydney (2000), to 1:00.17.{{cite news|title=Natalie Coughlin Finally Gets her Reward for Patience – Olympic Gold|url=http://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/lane9/news/7840.asp|publisher=[[Swimming World Magazine]]|date=16 August 2004|access-date=21 March 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130411215836/http://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/lane9/news/7840.asp|archive-date=11 April 2013|df=}} ==Records== Prior to this competition, the existing world and Olympic records were as follows. {{World Olympic Record | world_athlete = {{flagathlete|[[Natalie Coughlin]]|USA}} | world_mark = 59.58 | world_place = [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]], [[United States]] | world_date = 13 August 2002 | world_ref = | olympic_athlete = {{flagIOCathlete|[[Diana Mocanu]]|ROM|2000 Summer}} | olympic_mark = 1:00.21 | olympic_place = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] | olympic_date = 18 September 2000 | olympic_ref = }} The following new world and Olympic records were set during this competition. {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |- ! Date !! Event !! Name !! Nationality !! Time !!
